greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the number of Carmichael numbers of the form prime(n)*prime(n')*prime(n") with n > n' > n".
comment: The formula and PARI code uses Korselt's criterion. This sequence is a somewhat trivial variant of the more interesting sequence giving the number of Carmichael numbers of the form prime(n)*prime(n')*prime(n") with n < n' < n" (known to be finite for given n).
link: Amiram Eldar, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
formula: a(n) = # { pqr | p=prime(n) > q=prime(n') > r=prime(n") ; p-1 | pqr-1 ; q-1 | pqr-1 ; r-1 | pqr-1 }
example: a(7)=2 is the first nonzero term since 561 = 3*11*17 and 1105 = 5*13*17 are the two smallest Carmichael numbers and there's no other Carmichael number having prime(7)=17 as largest factor.
xref: Cf. A002997 and references therein ; A087788 ; A141703 ff.
results.author: _M. F. Hasler_, Jun 30 2008
